snippet.textDisplay: When you become a US citizen, and you're born in another country to parents that are not US citizens,  the US recognizes you as a US citizen only. Not a dual citizen.  Other countries outside of the US recognize you as dual citizen.  If you are born in another country but have parents that are US citizens, then you have dual citizenship.   There may be exceptions to the rule of course.
snippet.textOriginal: When you become a US citizen, and you're born in another country to parents that are not US citizens,  the US recognizes you as a US citizen only. Not a dual citizen.  Other countries outside of the US recognize you as dual citizen.  If you are born in another country but have parents that are US citizens, then you have dual citizenship.   There may be exceptions to the rule of course.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am 63 and the fact is the American Dream was designed for people born or pass for White. I have spent over half a century working my hardest with nothing to show for it but the daily experience of being treated with cynical suspicion and contempt, treated as an unwelcome foreigner in the land of my birth.

Better to live a foreigner in a foreign land, and never again worry about being arrested in my own home, arrested on suspicion while carrying at television out to my car, drive to a park for fresh air, take a nap and not be arrested for it, to be shot for no reason other than my race, to die knowing there will be no consequence for my random execution, and America's denial this is Terrorism.
snippet.textOriginal:
I am 63 and the fact is the American Dream was designed for people born or pass for White. I have spent over half a century working my hardest with nothing to show for it but the daily experience of being treated with cynical suspicion and contempt, treated as an unwelcome foreigner in the land of my birth.

Better to live a foreigner in a foreign land, and never again worry about being arrested in my own home, arrested on suspicion while carrying at television out to my car, drive to a park for fresh air, take a nap and not be arrested for it, to be shot for no reason other than my race, to die knowing there will be no consequence for my random execution, and America's denial this is Terrorism.

snippet.textDisplay: I've seen the citizenship test, and there's not a single question on it that wasn't covered in my grade school civics class. Also, football games aren't the only place in the UK where you see flag-waving. You'll see it on the last night of the Proms concerts at Royal Albert Hall, too. That's mostly Sir Malcolm Sargent's fault, but the custom is still going strong years after his death, and why wouldn't those people be proud of their country?
snippet.textOriginal: I've seen the citizenship test, and there's not a single question on it that wasn't covered in my grade school civics class. Also, football games aren't the only place in the UK where you see flag-waving. You'll see it on the last night of the Proms concerts at Royal Albert Hall, too. That's mostly Sir Malcolm Sargent's fault, but the custom is still going strong years after his death, and why wouldn't those people be proud of their country?

snippet.textDisplay: His was the entrance I wanted to make on my first day as an American Airman, but that would have been against regulations. snippet.textDisplay: My husband was an American who became a UK citizen. Like John Oliver (but in reverse of course) he was so nervous about gaining his citizenship as it was so important to him. snippet.textDisplay:
Too amazing! My 2 favorite talk show hosts on the same show!!!
You both are killer hilarious in your own way...
John congrats on your citizenship that a big thing! I'm envious cause I'm Canadian, are you bring your own unique flavour of British hilarity to the party!!!
Steven you are the King of American impressions!!! I can watch your Donald and Bernie are epic! I can watch you impersonate those 2 especially amongst others a billion times and it's still just as funny as the first!!!
Seriously I catch myself laughing the next day from what I saw the night before!!
Both of you are trail blazers of comedy going where no one has gone before,
Keep doin what your doin!!!
I'd love the opportunity to work with either one of you!
Being French Canadian I can do a pretty wicked impression of a Frenchman!
And let's face it...
Like you, I can make fun of my countrymen cause I am one!
You guys are awesome!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
Let’s examine the Left’s claims as to why Trump wanted to become president.


He did it to get more power:


If you are a billionaire in America, you already have all the power to do whatever you want in the world. Being president would simply expose you to hatred, accusations, endanger your family, and assassins. That’s not more power than being a billionaire, it is actually much less power. Your freedom of movement, time, and efforts are all restricted to the duties of an office.


He did it to get more money and influence:


Being president pays $400,000 a year. It also prevents you from doing personal business to make money. He doesn’t take the pay. The influence is primarily negative when you are president...when it comes to money...if you are already rich you most likely lose money you could have made.


He did it for attention:


No one would seek the kind of attention Trump has gotten from the Media and the Left. If Romney had beaten Obama...Trump would never have bothered with it. He made clear he didn’t want to do it. He backed candidates he tried to put in the office so he wouldn’t have to. People want positive attention.


He did it to control the world:


Actually he did it so the world would not be controlled, by the UN, by the Communists, by the Socialists, by the Fundamentalists, by the Left and the Liberals...who all want to control the world, rather than let the free markets, liberty, personal choice and merit work for everyone. He has no desire to control the world, and looks to make sure no one else tries to, like Iran, Russia, China, North Korea, Cuba, who would all stupidly try to control the world and the people if they could.


It’s a stupid argument: Trump took office to prevent the vary things the Left pretends to accuse him of. It’s an evil facade of accusing others of what they are guilty of...looking to simplify what was never simple, and shouldn’t be...that’s life.

snippet.textDisplay: I just wanted to say: very poor decision, but then he said he's got dual citizenship - great. Good decision to keep the UK passport.  My country of origin sadly doesn't allow dual citizenships, so I'll keep my passport and won't apply for citizenship because quite frankly right now I couldn't possibly be proud of being an American citizen. Keeping my original citizenship means I can travel to more countries without having to get a visa and I can go back to the EU should DT get a second term which will turn this country from a corrupt industrialized nation into a super corrupt banana republic. Plus of course as a citizen of my country of origin I'd always qualify for social services, which I may really need when I get older - you know, healthcare, retirement etc.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who recently naturalized myself, I feel John is giving a slightly bad impression of things.

Firstly, he could have naturalized MUCH easier than 2020 if he moved to the US in 2006. Assuming he arrived on a family based visa (very likely if he came in via his wife), he would have received a 2 year conditional stay with the ability to have the conditional status removed before the end of the 2 years; this is when you get your permanent residency (AKA green card).

Once the permanent residency is gained, the citizenship timer starts. If you are married to a US citizen, you are eligible to naturalize in 3 years from the date of gaining permanent residency. In John's case, that means he should have received permanent residency around 2008 and been eligible to naturalize around 2011. Even if the 3 year timer for marriage to a US citizen didn't apply, it would be a 5 year time instead, so he'd have been eligible in 2015. There's a bit of elasticity here based on processing times.

I arrived in the country 2 years before John and I naturalized last year. I could have filed MUCH earlier than I did.

As regards the civics test: it's not particularly difficult (at least, for native English speakers). They provide a book that contains all of the questions, and you just have to study it. In the interview you will be asked a random selection of questions from the study materials. Some of them are really easy ("Who is the current vice president of the United States?") and others are significantly harder (e.g. naming the states which initially formed the US). But the study materials are all provided, so it simply comes down to reading them. They're not trying to catch you out.

Just wanted to expand on this a bit in case anyone is thinking of filing and was put off by what they heard; it's really not as long as implied and it's not a horrible, terrifying experience either.

Being in the courtroom with people from 72 other countries and simultaneously making the oath is quite an experience, though!
snippet.textOriginal:
As someone who recently naturalized myself, I feel John is giving a slightly bad impression of things.

Firstly, he could have naturalized MUCH easier than 2020 if he moved to the US in 2006. Assuming he arrived on a family based visa (very likely if he came in via his wife), he would have received a 2 year conditional stay with the ability to have the conditional status removed before the end of the 2 years; this is when you get your permanent residency (AKA green card).

Once the permanent residency is gained, the citizenship timer starts. If you are married to a US citizen, you are eligible to naturalize in 3 years from the date of gaining permanent residency. In John's case, that means he should have received permanent residency around 2008 and been eligible to naturalize around 2011. Even if the 3 year timer for marriage to a US citizen didn't apply, it would be a 5 year time instead, so he'd have been eligible in 2015. There's a bit of elasticity here based on processing times.

I arrived in the country 2 years before John and I naturalized last year. I could have filed MUCH earlier than I did.

As regards the civics test: it's not particularly difficult (at least, for native English speakers). They provide a book that contains all of the questions, and you just have to study it. In the interview you will be asked a random selection of questions from the study materials. Some of them are really easy ("Who is the current vice president of the United States?") and others are significantly harder (e.g. naming the states which initially formed the US). But the study materials are all provided, so it simply comes down to reading them. They're not trying to catch you out.

Just wanted to expand on this a bit in case anyone is thinking of filing and was put off by what they heard; it's really not as long as implied and it's not a horrible, terrifying experience either.

Being in the courtroom with people from 72 other countries and simultaneously making the oath is quite an experience, though!
